item.title: Acoustic neuroma
item.description: Benign tumours of the Schwann cells surrounding the auditory nerve - also called vestibular schwannoma Found in the peripheral nervous system and provide the myelin sheath around the neurones

item.title: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo
item.description: Occurs on head movement due to disruption of small calcium crystals (canolithiasis) in the inner ear which can stimulate nerve endings causing dizziness

item.title: Epistaxis
item.description: Damage to the blood vessels of the nasal mucosa Causes/Factors Local Trauma Inflammation Topical drugs (corticosteroids) Surgery Vascular issues (hereditary haemorrhagic telangiectasia, [[Granulomatosis with polyangiitis]]) Tumours ([[Squamous cell carcinoma]]) General

item.title: Ménière's disease
item.description: Long term inner ear disorder that causes recurrent attacks of vertigo and symptoms of hearing loss and tinnitus. It is believed to result from excess fluid accumulation in the labyrinth, leading to increased pressure within the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear.

item.title: Obstructive Sleep Apnoea
item.description: Episodes of partial or complete airway occlusion during sleep. The obstruction can lead to poor quality sleep and leave the patient feeling fatigued in the morning despite thinking they got a good nights rest

item.title: Otitis Externa
item.description: Ear canal is the only skin-lined cul-de-sac in the body Acute - Symptoms < 3/52 Typically unilateral 90& bacterial, 2% fungal Chronic - Symptoms > 3/52 Often bilateral White keratin debris may fill the ear over time Allergic dermatitis to shampoos/cosmetics etc Treat underlying cause Causes/Factors Swimming Trauma Occlusive ear devices Allergic contact dermatitis Dermatological conditions Symptoms Inflammation of the external ear canal presenting with a combination of otalgia, pruritus and non-mucoid ear discharge Diagnostic Tests History Otoscopic examination Ear swab or pus sample for culture Management Topical antibiotic Gentamicin Corticosteroid Complications/red Flags Pseudomonas bacteria causing a necrotising OE -> life threatening

item.title: Otitis media
item.description: Middle ear infection Fluid present in middle ear Very uncommon in children Causes/Factors Viruses Similar bacteria as [[Otitis Externa]] Symptoms Uncomplicated

item.title: Pinna Cellulitis
item.description: Pinna Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection affecting the external part of the ear, known as the pinna or auricle. Associated with trauma (ear piercing & acupuncture) surgery or burns

item.title: Rhinosinusitis
item.description: Inflammation of the paranasal sinuses. Usually accompanied by inflammation of the nasal cavity - rhinosinusitis Acute < 12 weeks Chronic >12 weeks There are four sets of paranasal sinuses:

item.title: Sjögren's syndrome
item.description: Sjögren’s Syndrome is a chronic autoimmune disorder characterized by inflammation and dysfunction of the exocrine glands, primarily the salivary and lacrimal glands.

item.title: Tonsillitis & Pharyngitis
item.description: Causes/Factors Most commonly caused by viruses - rhino, corona, influenza, adeno Viral Infections: Common cold viruses (rhino, corona, adeno), flu viruses, and others can cause tonsillitis and pharyngitis.
